title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text: Data Explorer

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Learning objectives

Establish the concept of the project as the basic organizational unit of work.
Apply best practices in and leverage benefits of using a project-oriented workflow.


Creating robust file paths that travel well in time and space.
Constructing human and machine readable file names that sort nicely.
Differentiating workflow elements, analysis inputs, and analysis outputs in project structure to create navigable programming interfaces.
Restarting R frequently, with a blank slate.

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Prerequisites

install.packages(c("tidyverse", "devtools"))

devtools::install_github("r-lib/usethis")

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
section: Be organized as you go, not ‚Äútomorrow‚Äù
text:
Be organized as you go, not ‚Äútomorrow‚Äù


Don‚Äôt fret over past mistakes.




Raise the bar for new work.

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Prerequisite: Save code in scripts
Saving code is an absolute requirement for reproducibility. (Future you, future us)

Save commands as ‚Äúscripts‚Äù (.R) or ‚Äúnotebooks‚Äù (.Rmd).
It doesn‚Äôt have to be polished.
Just save it!
Everything that really matters should be achieved through code that you save
Contrast: Series of unrecorded mouse clicks

The process is important, the product is just an outcome

Outputs should be treated as disposable
Scripts are the source of truth

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Adopt a project-oriented workflow



Why

work on more than 1 thing at a time
collaborate, communicate, distribute
start and stop safely




How

dedicated directory
RStudio Project or Positron Workspace
Git repo, probably syncing to a remote



Project-oriented workflows

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
section: If the top of your script is
text:
If the top of your script is


setwd("C:/Users/andy/path/that/only/I/have")
rm(list = ls())


There is another path.


Project-oriented workflow designs this away. üôå


Project-oriented workflows

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Organize your work into projects
One folder per project.

Report? R package? Chapter? Website? Whatever.
Can be the same unit as a GitHub Repo.
If using RStudio, it‚Äôs Project (capital P)
If using Positron, it‚Äôs Workspace
Each Project gets its own R instance
R starts at the project root working directory: all paths are relative to the project‚Äôs folder.


Project-oriented workflows

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Organize your work into projects


my-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 01_read-data.R
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 02_clean-data.R
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 03_analysis.R
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ 04_output.R
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ R
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ data
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ derived_data
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ raw_data
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ outputs
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ paper
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ paper.qmd
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ references.bib



Project-oriented workflows

section: What does it mean to be an RStudio Project?
text:
What does it mean to be an RStudio Project?
Open Project = dedicated instance of RStudio

dedicated R process
file browser pointed at Project directory
working directory set to Project directory



RStudio leaves notes to itself in foo.Rproj

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
section: What does it mean to be a Positron Project Workspace?
text:
What does it mean to be a Positron Project Workspace?
Open Project = dedicated instance of Positron

dedicated R process
file browser pointed at Project directory
working directory set to Project directory



Often just a project folder that‚Äôs been opened in its own window via Open Folder or similar

.git/ directory
.Rproj file
.vscode/settings.json file
_quarto.yml file
DESCRIPTION file
renv.lock file
.here file

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Practice ‚Äúsafe paths‚Äù
The chance of setwd() having the desired effect ‚Äì making the file paths work ‚Äì for anyone besides its author is ~0%.
library(ggplot2)
setwd("/Users/andy/cuddly_broccoli/verbose/foofy/data")
df <- read.csv(‚Äúraw_foofy_data.csv‚Äù)
p <- ggplot(df, aes(x, y)) + geom_point()
ggsave("/Users/andy/cuddly_broccoi/ambiguous/fig.png")
 It‚Äôs also unlikely to work for the author one or two years or computers from now.
Hard-wired, absolute paths, especially when sprinkled throughout the code, make a project brittle. Such code does not travel well across time or space.

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Practice ‚Äúsafe paths‚Äù

relative to a stable base, not absolute paths.

use file system functions, not paste(), strsplit(), etc.

Working directory is associated with a specific process or running application.
When you open a project in RStudio or Positron, it sets the working directory to the project root - this is that ‚Äústable base‚Äù
‚ÄúWorking directory‚Äù as a concept is not comparable to ‚Äúhome directory‚Äù. ‚ÄúHome directory‚Äù is a static, persistent thing.

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Practice ‚Äúsafe paths‚Äù
Instead of:

setwd("C:/Users/andy/path/that/only/I/have")
my_data <- read.csv("data/my_data.csv")

Or:

my_data <- read.csv("C:/Users/andy/path/that/only/I/have/data/my_data.csv")

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Practice ‚Äúsafe paths‚Äù
Set your work up as an RStudio or Positron Project/Workspace and use relative paths:

my_data <- read.csv("data/my_data.csv")

Or:

my_data <- read.csv(file.path("data", "my_data.csv"))

section: Work on multiple projects at once
text:
Work on multiple projects at once
Because each project uses an isolated R process

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
section: Start R with a blank slate
text:
Start R with a blank slate



Save code for reproducibility.
When you quit: do not save the workspace to an .Rdata file.
When you start: do not reload the workspace from an .Rdata file.
In RStudio, set this via Tools > Global Options.
Or use usethis::use_blank_slate()






This is the default (and not customizable) in Positron

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Restart R often



Session -> Restart R




Windows

Ctrl + Shift + F10

Mac

Cmd + Shift + 0

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Project initiation: RStudio Project

New folder + make it an RStudio Project


usethis::create_project("~/i_am_new")
File -> New Project -> New Directory -> New Project


Make existing folder into an RStudio Project


usethis::create_project("~/i_exist")
File -> New Project -> Existing Directory

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Project initiation: Positron Workspace

New folder + make it a workspace


usethis::create_project("~/i_am_new", rstudio = FALSE)
File -> New Folder From Template


Open an existing directory as a workspace


usethis::create_project("~/i_exist", rstudio = FALSE)
File -> New Project -> Existing Directory

Note: if you don‚Äôt specify rstudio = FALSE, it will create an RStudio .Rproj file. This does no harm.


Try either option now with a folder containing (or that will contain) Bivalve Data 2014-2022_ICE.csv.

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Names machines like

don‚Äôt leave white space



use letters, numbers, hyphens and underscores‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs it  (characters like ^.*?+|$ can have a special meaning)




be consistent with case  (some operating systems treat a and A the same, some differently).




use separator characters wisely

¬† ¬† use underscore _ to separate different chunks
¬† ¬† use hyphen - for words in the same chunk



This creates names that are regular expression and globbing friendly, and easy to compute on! üéâ

Adapted from  https://djnavarro.net/slides-project-structure/#1.


Globbing: use of pattern matching against the names in a filesystem directory such that a name pattern is expanded into a list of names matching that pattern.

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Names humans like

name contains info on content
name anticipates context
concept of a slug üêå from user-friendly URLs

1986-01-28_raw-data-from-challenger-o-rings.txt
concise, meaningful description
usually appended to the end


Note: A URL slug is the part of the URL after the last backslash

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Names that sort nicely

put something numeric in there
left pad with zeros for constant width, nice sorting, 01
use the ISO 8601 standard for dates, YYYY-MM-DD
order = chronological or ‚Ä¶ consider common sense

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
ISO 8601







YYYY-MM-DD
ISO 8601

https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html


https://twitter.com/JennyBryan/status/816143967695687684

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
üëç file names

library(fs)
library(dplyr)

ft <- tibble(files = dir_ls("_examples/data/", glob = "*.csv"))


Intuitive sorting.



ft

# A tibble: 4 √ó 1
  files                                           
  <fs::path>                                      
1 _examples/data/2024-07-16_site-2_plot-data.csv  
2 _examples/data/2024-07-25_site-2_survey-data.csv
3 _examples/data/2024-08-12_site-1_plot-data.csv  
4 _examples/data/2024-08-18_site-1_survey-data.csv




arrange(ft, desc(files))

# A tibble: 4 √ó 1
  files                                           
  <fs::path>                                      
1 _examples/data/2024-08-18_site-1_survey-data.csv
2 _examples/data/2024-08-12_site-1_plot-data.csv  
3 _examples/data/2024-07-25_site-2_survey-data.csv
4 _examples/data/2024-07-16_site-2_plot-data.csv

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
üëç file names

library(stringr)

filter(ft, str_detect(files, pattern = "plot-data"))

# A tibble: 2 √ó 1
  files                                         
  <fs::path>                                    
1 _examples/data/2024-07-16_site-2_plot-data.csv
2 _examples/data/2024-08-12_site-1_plot-data.csv


Easy to filter in R (or the shell or whatever)

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
üëç file names

library(tidyr)

ft |> 
  mutate(files = path_ext_remove(files)) |> 
  separate(files, into = c("date", "site", "data_type"), sep = "_")

# A tibble: 4 √ó 3
  date  site                     data_type
  <chr> <chr>                    <chr>    
1 ""    examples/data/2024-07-16 site-2   
2 ""    examples/data/2024-07-25 site-2   
3 ""    examples/data/2024-08-12 site-1   
4 ""    examples/data/2024-08-18 site-1   


Intentional delimiters means meta-data is easily recovered.
_ delimits fields; - delimits words

Rename the file Bivalve Data 2014-2022_ICE.csv to something that is machine readable, human readable, and sorts nicely.
Read the file in to R using a relateive path

machine readable, human readable, and sort nicely


easy to implement NOW

payoffs accumulate as your skills evolve and  projects get more complex

R packages

R packages

the natural unit for distributing R code



base R

14 base + 15 recommended packages
ships with all binary distributions of R

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Additional packages


CRAN, ~20k packages

# install from CRAN
install.packages("devtools")
# attach
library(devtools)




GitHub ~‚àû packages

# install from GitHub
remotes::install_github("r-lib/devtools")
# attach
library(devtools)

development versions, or packages not on CRAN

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
section: R Libraries - where do packages live?
text:
R Libraries - where do packages live?

A library is a directory containing installed packages
You have at least one library on your computer
Common (and recommended) to have two libraries:

A system library with base (14) and recommended (15) packages; installed with R.
A user library with user-installed packages

We use library(pkg) function to attach a package
7 base packages are always attached (base, methods, utils, stats, grDevices, datasets, graphics)

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Where do packages live locally?

The system library (base/recommended packages).
.Library

All libraries for the current session
.libPaths()

All installed packages
installed.packages()

R Startup

.Rprofile - contains R code to be run at the start of each session.
.Renviron - contains environment variables to be set in R sessions.

set a default CRAN mirror
custom startup message

If it matters for code you share, it should not be in .Rprofile

library(tidyverse)
f <- dplyr::filter
theme_set(theme_bw())

text:
Customizing your IDE


Pane layout
Themes
Fonts
Positron extensions

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Keyboard shortcuts
If in doubt, use the command palette: Ctrl + Shift + P

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Navigation & Files

Ctrl + Shift + N - New file
Ctrl + S - Save current file
Ctrl + F - Find in current file
Ctrl + Shift + F - Find in files (global search)
Ctrl + . - Go to file/function
Ctrl + 1 - Focus source editor
Ctrl + 2 - Focus console

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Code Editing

Ctrl + Shift + C - Comment/uncomment lines
Tab - Indent selection
Shift + Tab - Unindent selection
Alt + Up/Down - Move line(s) up/down
Alt + Shift + Up/Down - Duplicate line(s) ???
Ctrl + X - Cut entire line (when no selection)

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Magic of Multiple Cursors

Ctrl + Alt + Up/Down - Add cursor above/below
Ctrl + D - Add next occurrence of selected text (custom)

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Navigation Within Code

Ctrl + Left/Right - Jump word by word
Home/End - Jump to beginning/end of line
Ctrl + Home/End - Jump to beginning/end of document
Ctrl + P - Jump to matching brace

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
R-Specific

Tab - Auto-complete
F1 - Show help for function under cursor
Ctrl + Shift + F10 - Restart R session
Ctrl + Shift + M - Insert pipe operator (%>% or |>)
Alt + - - Insert assignment operator (<-)

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
.Last.value
Shows last evaluated value in console
RStudio

Tools > Global Options > General > Advanced > Show .Last.value in environment listing

Positron
Controlled by an option:

usethis::edit_r_profile()
options(positron.show_last_value = TRUE)

title: Creating Efficient Workflows in R
text:
Automatic code formatting
Air: https://posit-dev.github.io/air/

In charge of the layout of your R code.
Formatters do not change the meaning of code
Ensure that whitespace, newlines, and other punctuation conform to a set of rules and standards


usethis::use_air()

title: Parks Canada - Intermediate R
text: This website contains the materials for the Parks Canada Intermediate R workshop. The workshop is designed to help participants improve their R programming skills, focusing on efficient workflows, , and reproducible research practices.

title: Parks Canada - Intermediate R
text:
Workshop Overview:
This intermediate R workshop is designed for data professionals and scientists who have basic R experience and want to advance their skills in data analysis and programming.
This will be an online, interactive workshop delivered virtually.

title: Parks Canada - Intermediate R
text:
Modules

1. Project-oriented workflows and effective use of your IDE (RStudio/Positron)


2. Version control and Collaboration with Git and GitHub


3. Advanced data manipulation with dplyr and tidyr


4. Programming with R - functions, functional programming, and iteration


5. Reproducible reporting with Quarto

title: Parks Canada - Intermediate R
text:
Exercises

Exercises for the data manipulation module can be found here.

title: Parks Canada - Intermediate R
text:
Prework
Please ensure you have completed the steps in System Setup.

title: Parks Canada - Intermediate R
text:
Instructor:
Andy Teucher is a freelance data scientist and package developer with a passion for teaching others how to use data science tools to make their work more efficient and reproducible. His background is in conservation biology, with an MSc in Ecology from the University of Calgary. He has spent much of his career as a data scientist in government, where he made it his mission to promote and teach open, reproducible data science practices. He has written many R packages for internal use in his teams as well as for a broader audience, with several hosted on CRAN. Andy is a certified Software Carpentry and Data Carpentry instructor, and has led many workshops teaching programming skills to scientists and data professionals.

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Outline


Today:

dplyr fundamentals review
Column-wise operations
Two-table verbs (joins)


Next time:

Window functions
Row-wise operations
Data reshaping with tidyr

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Data
Using data from the Portal Project
Long-term ecological research site studying the dynamics of desert rodents, plants, ants and weather in Arizona.
Data available from the GitHub repo via the portalr package.

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Setup

Create a new project in Positron


Either:

Fork and clone the exercises repository:
https://github.com/ateucher/pc-data-manipulation/ OR
Run:

usethis::use_course("https://github.com/ateucher/pc-data-manipulation/archive/refs/heads/main.zip")


Open the file: 01-get-data.R
Download the data:


install.packages("portalr")
library(portalr)

download_observations(".")


Explore the downloaded data in Positron

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Review of main dplyr operations

Selecting columns with select()
Filtering rows with filter()
‚ÄúSlice‚Äù rows with slice()/slice_*()
Creating new columns with mutate()
Summarizing data with summarize()



Grouping data with group_by() applies filter(), mutate(), and summarize() by group

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Warm-up
Read in the rodent capture data (PortalData/Rodents/Portal_rodent.csv).

Use readr::read_csv() and assign it to a data frame called rodents.
Standardize column names to use snake_case (hint: check out the janitor package)

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
dplyr practice



Remove records from invalid sampling periods (when period is negative). Re-assign the result to the rodents data frame.
How many individuals of each species were caught in 1995?
What date had the highest number of individual rodents caught?



Key columns

id = individual identifier
day, month, year = date of capture
period = sampling period
species = species code
wgt = weight (grams)
year = year of capture

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
dplyr practice



For each capture record, calculate the percent difference in weight from the average weight of that species.
Of all individual Ord‚Äôs Kangaroo Rats (species code ‚ÄúDO‚Äù) that have been caught more than 5 times, which individual was consistently the biggest? (i.e., has the highest average percent difference in weight from the species‚Äô average weight)?



Key columns

id = individual identifier
day, month, year = date of capture
period = sampling period
species = species code
wgt = weight (grams)
year = year of capture

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Column-wise operations

Apply one or more functions to a set of columns in a data frame using across()
Specfiy columns using selection helpers (e.g., starts_with(), ends_with(), contains(), where(), etc.)
Specify function(s) to apply to selected columns
Used with summarize() & mutate()


Example: calculate mean of all numeric columns

library(dplyr)
mtcars |>
  group_by(cyl) |>
  summarize(across(where(is.numeric), mean))



# A tibble: 3 √ó 11
    cyl   mpg  disp    hp  drat    wt  qsec    vs    am  gear  carb
  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
1     4  26.7  105.  82.6  4.07  2.29  19.1 0.909 0.727  4.09  1.55
2     6  19.7  183. 122.   3.59  3.12  18.0 0.571 0.429  3.86  3.43
3     8  15.1  353. 209.   3.23  4.00  16.8 0     0.143  3.29  3.5 




We are passing the function mean to across(), not calling it (i.e., no parentheses). Functions in R are objects that can be passed around and used later.

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Column-wise operations
specify multiple functions to apply in a list()


Example: calculate mean and sd of all numeric columns

library(dplyr)
mtcars |>
  group_by(cyl) |>
  summarize(
    across(where(is.numeric), list(mean = mean, sd = sd))
  )



# A tibble: 3 √ó 21
    cyl mpg_mean mpg_sd disp_mean disp_sd hp_mean hp_sd drat_mean drat_sd wt_mean wt_sd qsec_mean qsec_sd vs_mean vs_sd
  <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>
1     4     26.7   4.51      105.    26.9    82.6  20.9      4.07   0.365    2.29 0.570      19.1    1.68   0.909 0.302
2     6     19.7   1.45      183.    41.6   122.   24.3      3.59   0.476    3.12 0.356      18.0    1.71   0.571 0.535
3     8     15.1   2.56      353.    67.8   209.   51.0      3.23   0.372    4.00 0.759      16.8    1.20   0     0    
# ‚Ñπ 6 more variables: am_mean <dbl>, am_sd <dbl>, gear_mean <dbl>, gear_sd <dbl>, carb_mean <dbl>, carb_sd <dbl>




https://tidyselect.r-lib.org/reference/language.html

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Column-wise operations
Run this in your R session, what do you get?

library(dplyr)
penguins |>
  summarize(
    across(where(is.numeric), list(mean = mean, sd = sd))
  )



# A tibble: 1 √ó 10
  bill_len_mean bill_len_sd bill_dep_mean bill_dep_sd flipper_len_mean flipper_len_sd body_mass_mean body_mass_sd
          <dbl>       <dbl>         <dbl>       <dbl>            <dbl>          <dbl>          <dbl>        <dbl>
1            NA          NA            NA          NA               NA             NA             NA           NA
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: year_mean <dbl>, year_sd <dbl>





When we pass a function to across() it is passed with its default arguments

mean() and sd() both have an argument na.rm that defaults to FALSE

We can‚Äôt pass extra arguments to functions inside across() directly
We need to pass a function with the argument values we want ‚Äúbaked in‚Äù



https://tidyselect.r-lib.org/reference/language.html

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Specifying extra arguments
But if we‚Äôre doing this only once we can define them in place with an anonymous function:
\(x) function(x, other_args)

This defines a function ‚Äúon the fly‚Äù with the arguments specified how we want
The x will take the values of each column passed to it by across()


library(dplyr)

penguins |>
  summarize(
    across(
      where(is.numeric),
      list(
        mean = \(x) mean(x, na.rm = TRUE),
        sd = \(x) sd(x, na.rm = TRUE)
      )
    )
  )



# A tibble: 1 √ó 10
  bill_len_mean bill_len_sd bill_dep_mean bill_dep_sd flipper_len_mean flipper_len_sd body_mass_mean body_mass_sd
          <dbl>       <dbl>         <dbl>       <dbl>            <dbl>          <dbl>          <dbl>        <dbl>
1          43.9        5.46          17.2        1.97             201.           14.1          4202.         802.
# ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: year_mean <dbl>, year_sd <dbl>

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Your turn

Calculate the median of both types of bill measurements for each species in the built-in penguins dataset
Round all of the numeric colums in the PortalData/SiteandMethods/Portal_UTMCoords.csv dataset to 2 decimal places

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Two-table verbs (joins)




Mutatating joins

Combine two tables based on common values in one or more columns

Filtering joins

Filter rows from one table based on values in another table



https://r4ds.hadley.nz/joins.html#how-do-joins-work

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Mutating joins


left_join()

Keeps all rows in the left table
Drops rows from the right table that don‚Äôt match
Rows in the left that don‚Äôt match get NA in the columns from the right table





https://r4ds.hadley.nz/joins.html#how-do-joins-work

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Mutating joins


right_join()

Keeps all rows in the right table
Drops rows from the left table that don‚Äôt match
Rows in the right table that don‚Äôt match get NA in the columns from the left table





https://r4ds.hadley.nz/joins.html#how-do-joins-work

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Mutating joins


inner_join()

Keeps all rows in both tables where keys match
Rows from either table that don‚Äôt match are dropped





https://r4ds.hadley.nz/joins.html#how-do-joins-work

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Mutating joins


full_join()

Keeps all rows in both tables
Values in x and y that don‚Äôt match get NA in the result





https://r4ds.hadley.nz/joins.html#how-do-joins-work

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Join syntax
If don‚Äôt specify join columns, will join on all common names

E.g., both tables have columns year, month, day

left_join(x, y)
#> Joining with `by = join_by(year, month, day)`

Better to specify the join columns explicitly

Both tables have columns column_1 and column_2

left_join(x, y, by = c("column_1", "column_2"))

If the columns to join on have different names in each table

left_join(x, y, by = c("column_in_x" = "column_in_y"))

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Your turn
Use a join to add location information to the rodent captures data

The rodent captures data is in the PortalData/Rodents/Portal_rodent.csv file.
The SiteandMethods/Portal_UTMCoords.csv file contains information about the location of each plot

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Filtering joins


semi_join()

Keeps all rows in the left table where there are matching key values in the right table
Does not add any columns

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Filtering joins


anti_join()

Keeps all rows in the left table where there are not matching values in the right table
Does not add any columns

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Your turn
Use a join to find all the captures where the species is a granivore

The rodent captures data is in the PortalData/Rodents/Portal_rodent.csv file
The PortalData/Rodents/Portal_rodent_species.csv file contains information about the species

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
More complex joins using dplyr::join_by().
Cross joins create the full cartesian product of two tables


library(dplyr)
x <- data.frame(a = 1:3)
y <- data.frame(b = c("x", "y"))
cross_join(x, y)


  a b
1 1 x
2 1 y
3 2 x
4 2 y
5 3 x
6 3 y




Inequality joins
left_join(x, y, by = join_by(column_1 >= column_2))



Rolling joins (inequality joins constrained by closest())
left_join(
    x, y, 
    by = join_by(id, closest(capture_date >= survey_start_date))
)
Rolling joins are good for finding things like ‚Äúthe most recent rainy day before a survey date‚Äù


I haven‚Äôt found a good reason to use inequality joins, but they are a necessary precursor to rolling joins, which are very useful.

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Overlap joins


between(x, y_1, y_2)
within(x_1, x_2, y_1, y_2)
overlaps(x_1, x_2, y_1, y_2)

between(x, y_1, y_2):

  y_1 [‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê] y_2
         ‚Ä¢
         x


within(x_1, x_2, y_1, y_2):

  y_1 [‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê] y_2
         [‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê]
       x_1     x_2


overlaps(x_1, x_2, y_1, y_2):

  y_1 [‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê] y_2
                   [‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê‚ïê] 
                 x_1             x_2


https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/join_by.html#join-types

title: Advanced Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr
text:
Your turn
Using the rodent trapping data and the plant census dates data, join the two datasets to find out which plant census (year and season) each rodent capture is associated with.
Starting code:
library(dplyr)
library(readr)
library(lubridate)

plant_census_dates <- read_csv(
  "PortalData/Plants/Portal_plant_census_dates.csv",
  na = c("unknown", "none")
)

rodent_trapping <- read_csv("PortalData/Rodents/Portal_rodent_trapping.csv")

Hint: use an overlap join with between()

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
What is Git? 

A version control system
It tracks and manages the evolution of a set of files ‚Äî called a repository*
It keeps a history of changes to files, who made the changes, and when
It allows you to revert to previous versions of files
It enables collaboration by merging changes from multiple contributors
It is a command-line tool, but there are graphical user interfaces (GUIs) available


*repository (repo) == folder == RStudio or Positron project

Using a project-oriented workflow is critical

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text: Why Git?

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Why Git?

‚ÄúCommits‚Äù help us focus on the work, not the bookkeeping.
It takes care of otherwise time- consuming versioning & unrelenting file tracking.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Why GitHub? 


A commit is a snapshot of your project at a point in time.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
What is GitHub (traditional answer)?

GitHub is an online collaborative platform. It is built on top of Git - software that does file versioning and bookkeeping.
It is a remote host for your Git repositories.
It provides a web interface for managing, sharing, and collaborating on your repositories.
You can think of GitHub working like Dropbox - but with more control.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
What is GitHub (non-traditional answer)?

Publishing platform. A new way for sharing documentation & scicomm - your files can become websites! Share the url once, it‚Äôs always the latest version.
Project management system. Short- and long-term collaborative ‚Äútodo‚Äù lists: ‚ÄúIssues‚Äù & ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù


for most folks, the pros of Git only outweigh the cons once you take the additional step of hooking your local repository up to a remote host like GitHub. The joint use of Git and GitHub offers many benefits that more than justify the learning curve.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
GitHub account management

You can have one GitHub account for all of your work and personal projects
Add different email addresses to your GitHub account

work email for work projects
personal email for personal projects
associate activity with the correct email address

You can use multiple GitHub accounts, but it is more complicated to set up

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: An aside: set up your terminal in Positron
text:
An aside: set up your terminal in Positron

Unless you are already a Windows Powershell or Command Prompt user, I recommend switching the terminal in Positron to Git Bash.






Ctrl-Shift-PCtrl-Shift-P to open the command palette
search for "terminal default profile"
select Terminal: Select Default Profile‚Äù and set it to ‚ÄúGit Bash‚Äù.

settings.json
{
  "git.path": "C:/Program Files/Git/bin/bash.exe",
  "terminal.integrated.defaultProfile.windows": "Git Bash",
  "workbench.keybindings.rstudioKeybindings": true,
}

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Introduce yourself to Git
Configure your user.name and user.email for git. This information will be associated with your commits.


In the terminal
which git
git config --global user.name "Jane Doe"
git config --global user.email "jane@doe.ca"



In Positron or RStudio
usethis::use_git_config(
  user.name = "Jane Doe",
  user.email = "jane@doe.ca"
)

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: Check link between R and GitHub
text:
Check link between R and GitHub
Communicating with GitHub requires authentication with your GitHub account. This is achieved by creating and securely storing a Personal Access Token (PAT). The Managing Git(Hub) Credentials vignette in the usethis package has details on using PATs.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: Check link between R and GitHub
text:
Check link between R and GitHub
Create a PAT with:
usethis::create_github_token()


Give the token a descriptive name, accept the default scopes, and click ‚ÄúGenerate Token‚Äù.
Copy the newly generated PAT to your clipboard.
Run gitcreds::gitcreds_set() in R and paste in your PAT when prompted.
After you close the PAT webpage, you won‚Äôt be able to see your PAT again! You can store it somewhere secure, such as in a password manager.



You may need to install the gitcreds package.
Caveat about storing PATs on Linux:
macOS and Windows both have built-in credential managers that will securely store your PAT, however the same does not exist in Linux. Happy Git with R has a section on options for storing your PAT on Linux.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: Check your Git setup with a ‚Äúsituation report‚Äù
text:
Check your Git setup with a ‚Äúsituation report‚Äù
usethis::git_sitrep()


‚îÄ‚îÄ Git global (user)
‚Ä¢ Name: 'Andy Teucher'
‚Ä¢ Email: 'andy.teucher@gmail.com'
‚Ä¢ Global (user-level) gitignore file: '/Users/andy/.gitignore'
‚Ä¢ Vaccinated: TRUE
‚Ñπ Defaulting to 'https' Git protocol
‚Ä¢ Default Git protocol: 'https'
‚Ä¢ Default initial branch name: 'main'

‚îÄ‚îÄ GitHub user
‚Ä¢ Default GitHub host: 'https://github.com'
‚Ä¢ Personal access token for 'https://github.com': '<discovered>'
‚Ä¢ GitHub user: 'ateucher'
‚Ä¢ Token scopes: 'gist, repo, user, workflow'
‚Ä¢ Email(s): 'andy.teucher@gmail.com (primary)'
‚Ñπ No active usethis project

Personal access token for 'https://github.com': '<discovered>'



It is essential to check whether your name and email are correct and the PAT is showing as ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù


Do you see anything different in your output?


The output shows information about the link between RStudio and GitHub. Not all of it is relevant now, but it is essential to check whether your name and email are correct and the PAT is showing as ‚Äúdiscovered‚Äù
git_vaccinate()

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: We can interact with Git and GitHub:

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: Starting a new project with Git and GitHub
text:
Starting a new project with Git and GitHub

GitHub First

Create a new repo on GitHub, then clone it to your computer
Preferred, cleanest workflow 

Local First

Create a new repo on your computer, then push it to GitHub
Totally fine, a bit more awkward

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
We will:

Create a new repo on GitHub
Clone it to your computer and open as a new project using Positron
Create some commits
Push the commits to GitHub


We‚Äôre going to make a repository for recipes!
Organization:

README.md with a description of the project
one .md file per recipe in a recipes/ folder

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Making a commit

Make changes to file(s)
Choose what files you want to include in the commit
Stage the changes (using git add)
Commit the staged changes (using git commit)


If you think of Git as taking snapshots of changes over the life of a project, git add specifies what will go in a snapshot (putting things in the staging area), and git commit then actually takes the snapshot, and makes a permanent record of it (as a commit). It‚Äôs almost always better to explicitly add things to the staging area, because you might commit changes you forgot you made. Try to stage things manually, or you might find yourself searching for ‚Äúgit undo commit‚Äù more than you would like!

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
section: Converting an existing project to use Git and GitHub
text:
Converting an existing project to use Git and GitHub

Initialize a Git repository in your existing project
Commit the existing files
Create a new repo on GitHub
Link your local repo to the GitHub repo
Push the commits to GitHub

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Ignoring things

What about files that you don‚Äôt want to track with Git or put on GitHub?

large/sensitive data files,
rendered outputs,
temporary files created by IDE

.gitignore file in the root of your project



# R data files
*.RData
*.rda

# Specific data files
data/large_data.csv

# output files
reports/


Each line specifies a pattern
Comments starting with # are ignored
Wildcards (e.g., *) to specify patterns
Specify specific files or entire directories

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Create/add to a .gitignore file




Or
usethis::use_git_ignore(
  c("*.RData", "data/large_data.csv", "reports/")
)

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Your Turn

Find an existing project on your computer, and turn it into a git repository
Choose carefully* what files to include in your first commit, and commit the files
Create a new repository on GitHub and push your local commits to GitHub


Remember to use the .gitignore file



https://positron.posit.co/git.html

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Collaborating

Git is a distributed version control system
Each collaborator has a full copy of the repository, including its history
All collaborators can push changes to the remote repository (given they have permission)
Changes made by collaborators can be pulled into your local repository

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Your turn

In pairs, one person is the ‚Äúowner‚Äù of a repo, the other is a ‚Äúcollaborator‚Äù
Owner adds collaborator to a on GitHub
Collaborator clones the repo to their computer
Collaborator makes a change, commits, and pushes to GitHub
Owner pulls the change to their computer

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Collaborating via branching + ‚ÄúPull Requests‚Äù

More formal collaboration workflow
Allows fearless experimentation
Allows efficient code review and discussion
Good for bigger contributions






%%{
    init: {
        'theme':'base', 
        'showCommitLabel': false, 
        'themeVariables': { 
            'git0':'#6cc644', 
            'git1':'#f39c12', 
            'commitLabelColor': '#325c65', 
            'commitLabelBackground':'#325c65'
        }
    }
}%%

gitGraph
    commit id: " "
    commit id: "  "
    commit id: "   "
    commit id: "    "
    branch feature
    commit id: "     "
    commit id: "      "
    commit id: "       "
    commit id: "        "
    checkout main
    merge feature tag: "PR review & merge"
    commit id: "         "
    commit id: "          "

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Steps

Create a new branch
Make changes, commit, and push the branch to GitHub
Open a Pull Request (PR) on GitHub
Discuss and review the PR
Merge the PR into the main branch
Pull the latest changes to your local main branch

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Licensing and best practices

Share evidence, research and decision making openly. Make all non-sensitive data, information, and new code developed in delivery of services open to the outside world for sharing and reuse under an open licence.


It is recommended that the source code be released as early as possible in the project‚Äôs life cycle to avoid the overhead of publishing source code late in the process.


Employees should use their full name and Government of Canada email address for all code contributions to public repositories while acting within the scope of their duties or employment.


*https://canada-ca.github.io/open-source-logiciel-libre/en/open-source-standards.html
https://github.com/canada-ca/template-gabarit



Spend some time exploring this repo.
Can make a PR or open an issue if they want to contribute.
GitHub as a publishing platform.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Choose a license
For work

By default, a project without an open source licence applied to it would only be released under the Crown Copyright.


MIT is a good, permissive license for most projects
Apache 2.0 is similar, but adds an explicit patent grant

usethis::use_mit_license(
  copyright_holder = "His Majesty the King in Right of Canada, as represented by the Minister responsible for Parks Canada Agency"
)
For personal projects
usethis::use_mit_license(
  copyright_holder = "Andy Teucher"
)

https://github.com/canada-ca/open-source-logiciel-libre/blob/master/en/guides/publishing-open-source-code.md#select-open-source-software-licence



Show text of license
Explain I own the copyright, but anyone is free to borrow/use/modify it.

title: Version Control with Git and Collaboration with GitHub
text:
Your turn
Add a license to your repo via a pull request

title: System Setup ü§ñ
text: You will require the following software installed and configured for the workshop. Please have this set up and ready to go before we start.

title: System Setup ü§ñ
text:
Computing requirements
You will need:

A laptop computer with administrative privileges
R and RStudio
R package development toolchain
Several R packages
Git
GitHub account

title: System Setup ü§ñ
text:
Install R and RStudio
You will need:

R version >= 4.4.0
RStudio >= 2024.04 or Positron >= 2025.09.0-139


Install R
Download and install R for your operating system from https://cloud.r-project.org/.


Install R Studio
Download and install RStudio Desktop from https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/. This page should automatically offer you the version suitable for your operating system, but you can scroll down to find versions for all operating systems.


Install Positron
Download and install Positron from https://positron.posit.co/download.html. This page should automatically offer you the version suitable for your operating system, but you can scroll down to find versions for all operating systems.

title: System Setup ü§ñ
text:
Install R package development tools

For Windows
Download and run the latest Rtools installer, Rtools.exe, from https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/Rtools/.

Keep the default settings for the installation location and components to install
check the box to add rtools to the system PATH.



For Mac
Install XCode. The easiest way is to open a Terminal window (Applications > Utilities > Terminal.app; or use the Terminal pane in RStudio) and type the following:
xcode-select --install
You will be prompted to confirm the install, and possibly enter your computer password. Do so to complete the installation.
Alternatively you can:

Download and install XCode from the Mac AppStore: http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/xcode/id497799835?mt=12
Within XCode go to Preferences : Downloads and install the Command Line Tools



For Linux
If you installed r-base-dev when installing R, you should have all you need to build packages from source. If not, go back to https://cloud.r-project.org/ and follow the instructions for your distribution (Ubuntu and Debian are likely the most common, and install it with sudo apt-get install r-base-dev).

title: System Setup ü§ñ
text:
Git
We will be learning the use of Git and GitHub for version control and collaboration.

Windows
Check if Git is installed by running which git in the Terminal pane in RStudio.
If which git didn‚Äôt find Git installed:

Download and install from https://git-scm.com/downloads
Keep all the default settings. If asked about ‚ÄúAdjusting your PATH environment‚Äù, make sure to select ‚ÄúGit from the command line and also from 3rd-party software‚Äù.


RStudio + Git

Open RStudio. In the menus go to Tools > Global Options > Git/SVN.
Check RStudio has found git under ‚ÄúGit executable‚Äù. If it hasn‚Äôt:

You may need to click Browse and find the git executable.
It may be in C:/Users/[username]/AppData/Local/Programs/Git/




Positron + Git

Positron is smart about finding git, but if it doesn‚Äôt find it automatically:
In the menu go to File > Preferences > Settings.
Search for ‚ÄúGit Path‚Äù.

Click ‚ÄúEdit in settings.json‚Äù and add the path to the git executable.
It may be in C:/Users/[username]/AppData/Local/Programs/Git/cmd/git.exe





Mac
Check if Git is installed by running which git in the Terminal. You should see something like /usr/bin/git, /usr/local/bin/, or /opt/homebrew/bin/git.
If you are asked to install the Xcode command line tools, say yes.
If which git didn‚Äôt find Git installed, and if you weren‚Äôt prompted to install it, run the following in the Terminal: xcode-select --install


If you do lots of scientific computing and especially if you use command-line programs in the Terminal, we recommend using Homebrew. See brew.sh for installation instructions. To install Git using Homebrew, run the following in the Terminal: brew install git

title: System Setup ü§ñ
text:
GitHub
Register a GitHub account at github.com.
I highly recommend the book Happy Git with R for advice on setting up and using Git with R [@bryan].

Troubleshooting
If you are having issues with the setup please start a discussion on GitHub here.
